ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Theory of commutative rings, modules, categories and functors, and applications.

The basic results and tools of commutative algebra (and some category theory), which is very important in many algebraic fields (algebraic number theory, geometry, topology, etc...).  See the syllabus for more details, I guess.
I learned tensor products, modules, category theory, a bit of algebraic geometry. I also learned to problem solve better
Properties of Rings/Modules, Basic Category Theory.
Commutative algebra (module theory) and some category theory
I felt I gained a lot of maturity in using the language of module theory and category theory.
Learned the foundations of commutative algebra and some very basic algebraic geometry.
General commutative algebra, basic algebraic geometry
Extension of the commutative ring theory taught in MATH 350, lots of module theory, basics of category theory, basics of algebraic geometry

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material is essential despite being a little boring at times. Junliang is a great strength of the course. He's a very good lecturer and posts clear notes online. Profesor Shen manages to give some applications and motivation for the more boring parts of the class.

The material itself is pretty cool, since many of the things you learn about modules and even category theory generalize and combine results and intuitions from previous courses.  I feel like the course gives a more unified theory of how a lot of algebra work and fits together.  The main strength of the course, however, is Professor Shen.  He is great: engaging, approachable, enthusiastic, etc....  Psets are pretty doable and not that stressful, but I still feel like they did a good job at reinforcing the material.

Strengths: organization is great, content is super cool and interesting. Problem sets problems are constructed so that they are illuminative and help you learn the material much better without being onerous 

Weaknesses: none at all

Strengths:
Prof. Shen is a very energetic and passionate teacher. The course material is inherently dry, but he was able to do a good job keeping it motivated (mainly through connections to algebraic geometry). Also, the pset feedback/grading is consistently given within one week, which I appreciated.

Weaknesses:
I wish the course allocated more time towards the later topics (tensor products/tensor-hom adjunction, the nullstellensatz, etc.) - I feel like too much time is spent reviewing rings + going over modules (especially since everyone has seen rings before, and most people, even if they haven't seen modules, are  comfortable with vector spaces/linear algebra, a lot of which transfers over).
I learned a lot throughout this course, and it was well organized. The homework was a good review of the in class material. The final exam was more challenging, but still reasonable.
Very well structured and clear, lecture notes followed class extremely well. Homework and exam was reasonable and tested material covered.

The biggest strengths were professor Shen (awesome teacher, really good at explaining, unparalleled chalkboardwork), and the organization of the course. The biggest weakness was the dryness of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. If you want to do anything algebraic you want to take this class. If Shen teaches it you may want to take the class even if you're not into algebra. Just to witness clear teaching and magnificent boardwork is enough.
Yes. The course provides a wide range of knowledge in commutative algebra.
Yes.  It's very useful for tons of other math, and Shen is a great prof.
Yes, any serious mathematics student needs to take this class. It is foundation and everything shows up later in math
Math majors who are interested in algebra.
If you are interested in graduate study of algebra, this is a great class to take!
Yes. I think it is essential mathematical knowledge and extremely well taught.
Yes. Although this is not technically the prerequisite for a lot of other classes, I believe its better to have it because it helps one understand stuff much better.
Yes, the course was well organized, and I learned a lot
Yes, especially with Junliang. Very passionate about the subject and teaching, and very good at communicating ideas.

if youre planning to study algebraic geometry in more depth, i would recommend this class. junliang is a very good lecturer: he gives organized lectures, moves at a good pace, and frequently provides intuition for definitions and proofs. he is also very helpful and clear in office hours. the workload was very low for a math class  our weekly psets only had three questions each, and there was no midterm. however, the class content could be a little dry at times, because the course is really designed to give you the ring and module theory background to take other math courses like algebraic geometry in the future.
Yes, if you want to study algebra for a living; no, if you don't.
